Hyperbolic Identities

The hyperbolic functions \(\cosh x\) and \(\sinh x\) satisfy similar (but not exactly equivalent) identities to those satisfied by \(\cos x\) and \(\sin x\). We note first some basic notation similar to that employed with trigonometric functions: \(\cosh^nx\) means \((\cosh x)^n\), \(\sinh^nx\) means \((\sinh x)^n\) for \(n\ne -1\). 

In the special case that \(n=-1\) we do not use \(\cosh^{-1}x\) and \(\sinh^{-1}x\) to mean the reciprocals of the expressions. The notation \(\cosh^{-1}x\) and \(\sinh^{-1}x\) is reserved for the inverse functions of \(\cosh x\) and \(\sinh x\) respectively.
